definitions.definition: to change something completely so that it is the opposite of what it was before

examples.text: Falling birth rates may **reverse the trend** towards early retirement.
to reverse a procedure/process
The government has failed to reverse the economic decline.
It is sometimes possible to arrest or reverse the disease.

definitions.definition: to change a previous decision, law, etc. to the opposite one

examples.text: The Court of Appeal **reversed the decision**.
The policy is likely to be reversed if there is a change of government.
to reverse a judgement

definitions.definition: to turn something the opposite way around or change the order of something around

examples.text: Writing is reversed in a mirror.
You should reverse the order of these pages.
To solve the puzzle, simply reverse the order of the numbers.

definitions.definition: to exchange the positions or functions of two things

examples.text: It felt as if we had reversed our roles of parent and child.
She used to work for me, but our situations are now reversed.

definitions.definition: to admit you were wrong or to stop having a particular position in an argument

examples.text: He has reversed himself on a dozen issues.

definitions.definition: when a vehicle or its driver reverses or the driver reverses a vehicle, the vehicle goes backwards

examples.text: He reversed around the corner.
She reversed into a parking space.
Caution! This truck is reversing.
Now reverse the car.
He reversed slowly out of the garage.
She carefully reversed the lorry up the narrow driveway.
The car reversed into a hedge.

definitions.definition: to make a phone call that will be paid for by the person you are calling, not by you

examples.text: I want to reverse the charges, please.

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French revers, reverse (nouns), reverser (verb), from Latin reversus ‘turned back’, past participle of revertere, from re- ‘back’ + vertere ‘to turn’.
